THE BUZZ — BERNIE MOVEMENT REJECTS GAVIN: Bernie Sanders may not be the Democratic nominee, but his followers are flexing their muscle in California, where he handily won the March 3 primary. And those grassroots Democratic activists last weekend rejected Gavin Newsom when they voted to name who will lead them into this summer’s Democratic National Convention. Their choices: Rep. Ro Khanna of Silicon Valley, the most prominent and high profile backer of Bernie Sanders’ presidential run, along with Rep. Barbara Lee of Oakland, an icon to the progressive crowd. And representing the more moderate wing of the party will be Los Angeles County Supervisor Hilda Solis, who served as secretary of labor during the Obama administration. The grassroots decision to sidestep Newsom was a clear departure from tradition — and a signal that progressives who backed Sanders don’t intend to be sidelined. Party insiders say Newsom — who endorsed Hillary Clinton over Sanders in 2016, and Kamala Harris over Sanders in 2020 — wanted to lead the Democratic Party delegation of his state. But the California governor pulled out of the competition after groups like the California Nurses Association, still angered at what they saw as a backtrack on single-payer health care, and Sanders’ own Our Revolution crowd made clear he wouldn’t make the cut. After the vote, Newsom tweeted Sunday that “CA Democrats have never been more energized, united and ready to elect our next President.” BERNIE BACKERS NOD FOR KHANNA AS MOVEMENT LEADER? The vote underscored Khanna’s rise as a progressive wing leader to watch — and cements his role as the captain of the Bernie movement in California. The national co-chair of Sanders’ campaign was a valued surrogate for the Vermont senator and helped deliver 46 of 52 districts for Sanders in the March 3 primary. He has galvanized progressive support with his active legislative record to curb the president’s war powers and end U.S. involvement in the Saudi-lead war in Yemen, among other issues. Khanna tells POLITICO that the support sends the message that “California is leading the way” on a score of issues that he’s fought for, and which matter to progressive voters — including free public college, single payer, clean tech, rethinking military and police budgets, and criminal justice reform. “This is not a ceremonial role,’’ he said. “We’ll be pushing for a progressive agenda ... and for a start to a new progressive era.” NOT YOUR FATHER’S POLITICAL CONVENTION: Khanna acknowledges in the age of Covid-19, it is unlikely that any of the Democratic National Convention will be a traditional party get-together. And he’s glad. “It’s irresponsible what the GOP is doing,’’ holding a convection indoors with packed delegates and exposing them to coronavirus transmission, he said. “Prudence and caution is what we need now.” So he, Lee and Solis may miss that big TV moment of delivering California’s delegates to Biden amid a big crowd and in front of the TV cameras. But “I’m perfectly happy,’’ he said, “to do it on Zoom.” BUENOS DÍAS, good Monday morning. Newsom’s noon briefing today on Covid will likely cover his latest move — pushing for shutdowns of bars in a score of counties that are seeing alarming uptickes in coronavirus transmission. QUOTE OF THE DAY: “If I was offered it? Of course I would .… But my focus is doing everything I can so that next January, we are relieved from going through what we’ve been through in the last three and a half years.” CA Rep. Karen Bass, asked by Fox 11’s Elex Michaelson, if she would accept the VP slot should Joe Biden offer it. TWEET OF THE DAY: USAF veteran @KimMangone, the Democrat running against House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy — “Hey @GOPLeader, your silence on Trump cozying up to Putin is an endorsement of Russia putting bounties on the lives of my brothers and sisters. And it’s utterly indefensible.” WHERE’S GAVIN? The governor will deliver his #NewsomAtNoon briefing with Covid-19 updates, streamed on Twitter @CAGovernor and Facebook California Governor websites. urn:contentItem:5PJ8-4CC1-DY9P-N10H-00000-00Khan's message is that London is shut to innovation and enterprise;Uber crisis2017-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:14ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 30Khan's message is that London is shut to innovation and enterpriseUber crisisSAM DUMITRIU

Sadiq Khan won a landslide victory on a record turnout to become London Mayor. That's a big mandate, but it's nothing compared to the innovative ride-sharing firm he's decided to take on. Three and a half million Londoners regularly use Uber. That is more than twice as many people who voted for Mr Khan.

There's this mistaken idea that democracy is simply ticking a box every four years. It's not. We do not give elected politicians free rein between elections, rather we expect them to listen and do their very best to implement the will of the people.

Politicians can gauge public opinion in a number of ways. They might compare petitions. GMB, the trade union, presented a 100,000 signature petition to TfL last Monday calling for Mr Khan to kick Uber out of London. Last year Uber was threatened with a new wait-time regulation: 200,000 people signed that petition.

At the time of writing, Uber's petition to stay in London is at over 230,000 signatures and increasing by 250 every couple of seconds.

Opinion surveys are another. Polling firms rake in millions from newspapers, political parties and businesses with the promise of finding out what the public thinks.

But the lesson of Brexit, Trump and Corbyn is that people often say one thing and do another. But, there is a better way to work out what voters really want: check their bank statements.

And if you check the monthly bank statement of the average Londoner, you'll see with over a million trips each week that they've cast their sterling votes for Uber and not black cabs.

And it's easy to see why. Uber offers a substantially cheaper service, payment by card and shorter waittimes.

TfL have censured Uber on the grounds of safety, in particular focusing on the reporting of sexual assaults. That's a serious issue, but TfL should listen to the women who will always opt for an Uber late at night. Shorter waiting times mean that long walks in search of a main road to hail a cab are no longer necessary, and with every trip logged and tracked by GPS female passengers feel safer.

Others like the GMB union attack Uber for supposedly exploiting its 40,000 strong force of drivers. They argue that Uber drivers are being denied basic workers' rights like sick pay, holiday leave, and the minimum wage. But, Uber drivers are free to work for other providers, they choose their own hours, and when they were polled last year 80pc said they wouldn't trade additional workers' rights for a reduction in flexibility.

Yet, the strongest evidence is that so many drivers stick with Uber, in the face of aggressive competition from rival apps and private-hire firms.

Political thinkers often worry that big tech firms such as Amazon, Google and Facebook have become more powerful than governments. They've got it backwards.

The reason that Facebook refuses the Government's attempts to decrypt WhatsApp messages isn't because Facebook is all powerful, but because, after the NSA leaks, consumers demand it. In this era, it's the consumer that is sovereign.

For many of Uber's 3.5m users, today will be a political awakening. Consumers have become used to a world where companies like Airbnb, Amazon and Uber are free to operate unencumbered by big government. Mr Khan's announcement has changed that.

After the EU referendum, Sadiq Khan has passionately argued for a modern, open London. By revoking Uber's licence he will have defined himself in the eyes of 3.5m Uber users in London as the mayor who closed the capital to competition, innovation and business.

Sam Dumitriu is head of projects at the Adam Smith Institute

urn:contentItem:5BV6-K881-JCPJ-W3VF-00000-00Kickstarting isn't investing, Oculus deal reminds true believers2014-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:06:14ZLexisNexisKickstarting isn't investing, Oculus deal reminds true believersBen Fischer

With the passage of time, Kickstarter and Oculus VR Inc. are getting plenty of defenders.

In the immediate aftermath of Facebook's $2 billion acquisition of the virtual reality screen manufacturer, many of the company's original funders from the Greenpoint-based crowd funding platform  were angry- surprised to learn that the passion project they backed might also be valued by Big Tech.

But those concerns have been almost universally pooh-pooh'd by industry insiders I've spoken with today (and  plenty of tech  journalists too.)

"Oculus is actually the perfect example of how 'traditional' rewards-based crowdfunding should and does work," veteran Manhattan angel investor David S. Rose told me. "A great idea was nurtured and supported by early adopters, who took a chance and placed an up-front order for a product they wanted, but that didn't exist yet. That proof of market demand, early cash and leap of faith, was enough for the company to develop the product, which its supporters will get, exactly as intended."

Rose, CEO of Gust Inc., suggests it's revisionist history for any Kickstarter funder to conflate their own donation with an investment. At best, it was a purchase: an Oculus Rift development kit in appreciation for the donation.

"Do you expect to own a piece of Amazon just because you bought a book from them?" Rose asked rhetorically. "Or are you entitled to a percentage of an artist's lifetime earnings, just because you bought a painting from her when she was starving on a sidewalk?"

However, the lack of logical or legal basis to complain doesn't mean funders won't think twice about donating in the future, said Michael Schwamm, a corporate lawyer who advises early-stage companies. He thinks future Kickstarter campaigns will be scrutinized more closely by would-be funders who suspect a project could get backing elsewhere, or suspect it might not be the passion project it purports to be.

"I would never kickstart a Google project or a Facebook project, and that's effectively what happened in this case," said Schwamm, a partner at Duane Morris LLP in Times Square.

Then again, startups could never promise to not sell a company in the future, and they're prohibited by law to promise equity in exchange for dollars on Kickstarter.

"It's going to be interesting how it plays out, but I really do think this is going to be a landscape changer for some companies," Schwamm told me.

The easy answer to all this could be the new SEC rules governing true crowdfunding - the  long-stalled regulations that will lay out a legal framework for actual equity-based investments at the level Kickstarter operates. 

"While the expectations right now ARE set outright, meaning you get X for Y, I think it would be an even greater story if a bunch of folks that contributed to this idea would have been involved in the exit money," said Anthony Onesto, a Staten Island digital business advisor. "It truly democratizes fund raising to the average person with a potential return greater than just obtaining the product."
